A major contributor to this article appears to have a close connection with its subject. It may require cleanup to comply with Wikipedia's content policies, particularly neutral point of view. Please discuss further on the talk page. (August 2015) (Learn how and when to remove this template message)

Infodemiology (and the closely related term infoveillance) is a term coined by Canadian researcher Gunther Eysenbach. Eysenbach defines "infodemiology" (or information epidemiology) as a "new research discipline and methodology [which deals with] the study of the determinants and distribution of health information [on the Internet]", with the ultimate goal to improve public health[1][2][3]

Eysenbach first used the term in the context of measuring and predicting the quality of health information on the web (i.e., measuring the "supply" side of information).[1] He later included into his definition methods and techniques which are designed to automatically measure and track health information "demand" (e.g., by analyzing search queries) as well as "supply" (e.g., by analyzing postings on webpages, in blogs, and news articles, for example through GPHIN) on the Internet with the overarching goal to inform public health policy and practice. In 2013, the Infovigil Project was launched in an effort bring the research community together to help realize this goal, and is funded by the Canadian Institutes of Health Research.[4]

Eysenbach demonstrated his point by showing a correlation between flu-related searches on Google (demand data) and flu-incidence data.[2] The method is shown to be better and more timely (i.e., can predict public health events earlier) than traditional syndromic surveillance methods such as reports by sentinel physicians.

Researchers have applied an infodemiological approach to studying the spread of HIV/AIDS,[5] SARS[6] and influenza,[7][8][9], vaccination uptake[10][11][12], antibiotics consumption[13], the incidence of multiple sclerosis,[14][15] patterns of alcohol consumption,[16] the efficacy of using the social web for personalization of health treatment,[17][18] the contexts of status epilepticus patients,[19][20] and the effectiveness of the Great American Smokeout anti-smoking awareness event.[21] Applications outside the field of health care include urban planning[22] and the study of economic trends and voter preferences.[23]

See also[edit]

  • Global Public Health Intelligence Network
  • Innovative Support to Emergencies, Diseases, and Disasters (InSTEDD) Larry Brilliant's proposed infodemiology system by, can be seen as supply-side infodemiology systems
  • JMIR E-Collection Infodemiology
  • JMIR Public Health & Surveillance E-Collection Infoveillance, Infodemiology and Digital Disease Surveillance
